an6.44:4.1: Then Venerable Ānanda got dressed in the morning and, taking his bowl and robes, went to the home of the laywoman Migasālā,
an6.44:4.2: where he sat on the indicated seat.
an6.44:4.3: Then the laywoman Migasālā went up to Ānanda,
an6.44:4.4: bowed, sat down to one side,
an6.44:5.1: “Sir, Ānanda, how on earth are we supposed to understand the teaching taught by the Buddha, when the chaste and the unchaste are both reborn in exactly the same place in the next life?
an6.44:5.2: My father Purāṇa was celibate, set apart, avoiding the common practice of sex.
an6.44:5.3: When he died the Buddha declared that he was a once-returner, who was reborn in the group of Joyful Gods.
an6.44:5.4: But my uncle Isidatta was not celibate; he lived content with his wife.
an6.44:5.5: When he died the Buddha declared that he was also a once-returner, who was reborn in the group of Joyful Gods.
an6.44:5.6: How on earth are we supposed to understand the teaching taught by the Buddha, when the chaste and the unchaste are both reborn in exactly the same place in the next life?”
an6.44:5.7: “You’re right, sister, but that’s how the Buddha declared it.”
an6.44:6.1: Then Ānanda, after receiving almsfood at Migasālā’s house, rose from his seat and left.
an6.44:6.2: Then after the meal, on his return from alms-round, Ānanda went to the Buddha,
an6.44:6.3: bowed, sat down to one side,
an6.44:6.4: and told him what had happened.
an6.44:8.1: “Ānanda, who is this laywoman Migasālā, a foolish incompetent auntie, with an auntie’s wit? And who is it that knows how to assess individuals?
an6.44:8.2: These six people are found in the world.
an6.44:9.2: Take a certain person who is sweet-natured and pleasant to be with. And spiritual companions enjoy living together with them.
an6.44:9.3: But they’ve not listened or learned or penetrated by view or found even temporary freedom.
an6.44:9.4: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re headed for a lower place, not a higher. They’re going to a lower place, not a higher.
an6.44:10.1: Take another person who is sweet-natured and pleasant to be with. And spiritual companions enjoy living together with them.
an6.44:10.2: And they’ve listened and learned and penetrated by view and found temporary freedom.
an6.44:10.3: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re headed for a higher place, not a lower. They’re going to a higher place, not a lower.
an6.44:11.2: ‘This one has just the same qualities as the other, so why is one worse and one better?’
an6.44:11.3: This will be for their lasting harm and suffering.
an6.44:12.1: In this case, the person who is sweet-natured … and has listened, learned, penetrated by view, and found temporary freedom
an6.44:12.2: is better and more excellent than the other person.
an6.44:12.4: Because the stream of the teaching carries them along. But who knows this difference except a Realized One?
an6.44:12.5: So, Ānanda, don’t be judgemental about people.
an6.44:12.7: Those who pass judgement on people harm themselves.
an6.44:12.8: I, or someone like me, may pass judgement on people.
an6.44:13.1: Take another person who is angry and conceited, and from time to time has greedy thoughts.
an6.44:13.2: And they’ve not listened or learned or penetrated by view or found even temporary freedom.
an6.44:13.3: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re headed for a lower place, not a higher. They’re going to a lower place, not a higher.
an6.44:14.1: Take another person who is angry and conceited, and from time to time has greedy thoughts.
an6.44:14.2: Because the stream of the teaching carries them along. But who knows this difference except a Realized One?
an6.44:14.3: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re headed for a better place, not a worse. They’re going to a better place, not a worse.
an6.44:15.2: I, or someone like me, may pass judgement on people.
an6.44:16.1: Take another person who is angry and conceited, and from time to time has the impulse to speak inappropriately.
an6.44:16.2: And they’ve not listened or learned or penetrated by view or found even temporary freedom.
an6.44:16.4: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re headed for a lower place, not a higher. They’re going to a lower place, not a higher.
an6.44:17.1: Take another person who is angry and conceited, and from time to time has the impulse to speak inappropriately.
an6.44:17.2: But they’ve listened and learned and penetrated by view and found temporary freedom.
an6.44:17.3: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re headed for a higher place, not a lower. They’re going to a higher place, not a lower.
an6.44:18.2: ‘This one has just the same qualities as the other, so why is one worse and one better?’
an6.44:18.4: This will be for their lasting harm and suffering.
an6.44:19.1: In this case, the person who is angry and conceited, but has listened, learned, penetrated by view, and found temporary freedom
an6.44:19.2: is better and more excellent than the other person.
an6.44:19.4: Because the stream of the teaching carries them along.
an6.44:19.5: But who knows this difference except a Realized One?
an6.44:19.6: So, Ānanda, don’t be judgemental about people.
an6.44:19.8: Those who pass judgement on people harm themselves.
an6.44:19.9: I, or someone like me, may pass judgement on people.
an6.44:20.1: Who is this laywoman Migasālā, a foolish incompetent auntie, with an auntie’s wit? And who is it that knows how to assess individuals?
an6.44:20.2: These six people are found in the world.
an6.44:21.1: If Isidatta had achieved Purāṇa’s level of ethical conduct,
an6.44:21.2: Purāṇa could not have even known Isidatta’s destination.
an6.44:21.3: And if Purāṇa had achieved Isidatta’s level of wisdom,
an6.44:21.4: Isidatta could not have even known Purāṇa’s destination.
an6.44:21.5: So both individuals were lacking in one respect.”
